bites.bite: In Turkmenistan, there are 21 funder_ref(s) working in 30 sector_group(s).
The largest sector_group is Basic health with 60 reports followed by Government and civil society, general with 55 reports.
The largest activity_url is http://d-portal.org/q.html?aid=US-GOV-1-AID-GHA-G-00-09-00003 with 19 reports followed by http://d-portal.org/q.html?aid=US-GOV-1-7200AA19F00014 with 14 reports.
The largest funder_ref is XM-DAC-928 with 112 reports followed by US-GOV-1 with 97 reports.
The largest reporting is World Health Organization with 112 reports followed by U.S. Agency for International Development with 97 reports.
The largest reporting_ref is XM-DAC-928 with 112 reports followed by US-GOV-1 with 97 reports.

bite: Worldwide adaptation and implementation of the global strategy and targets for tuberculosis prevention, care and control after 2015 as adopted in resolution WHA67.1

Updated policy guidelines and technical tools to support the adoption and implementation of the global strategy and targets for tuberculosis prevention, care and control after 2015, covering the three pillars: (1) integrated, patient-centred care and prevention; (2) bold policies and supportive systems; and (3) intensified research and innovation

The provision of a senior loan of up to US$ 2.7 million to support the  expansion of a strawberry greenhouse owned by ES Hilli Gaplama, a limited  liability company registered in Turkmenistan. The increased greenhouse will  annually yield 300 tonnes of berries vs. 58 tonnes, which are expected to be  harvested in 2020. The Project will be implemented in two phases.
European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
The provision of US$ 0.5 million loan to finance working capital needs of  Turkmenin Rysgaly, one of the leading producers of hygienic products in  Turkmenistan
European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

The provision of a senior secured loan of up to US$ 1.5 million (€1.3 million)  to Individual Enterprise "Alem Gamisi". The operation will enable the Company  to ensure the continuity of potato chips production during the COVID-19 crisis  by mitigating the risk of possible disruption in supply of imported raw  materials.  This project was approved in the context of the Bank's response to the  COVID-19 pandemic. To avoid delays to the delivery of this project, the Bank's  President granted a deviation from the ordinary timelines for PSD disclosure,  as contemplated by Section V of the Directive on Access to Information.   Details of the Bank's response to COVID-19, and this deviation, can be found on  our website.
European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

The HCFC Phase-out Management Plan (HPMP) is developed to enable Turkmenistan to meet the obligations under the Montreal Protocol and its Amendments. It has been prepared in cooperation with the Government of Turkmenistan by NOU, UNIDO and UNEP. The HPMP has been formulated following the process and guidance provided by the relevant decisions of the Meeting of the Parties of the Montreal Protocol and the Executive Committee of the Multilateral Fund.

This HPMP for Turkmenistan will be implemented through the combination of investment and non-investment activities in the refrigeration and air-conditioning service sectors of Turkmenistan over a period of five years for Stage I and will result in a phase out of 10% by 2015, 35% by 2020 and Stage II from 2020 till 2040 in a complete phase out of 100%


The main elements of the first stage are: enhancement of legislation relating HCFC phase out, training of customs officers, training in the refrigeration sector, support to R&R centres, training of the staff of the state laboratory and monitoring. The Government made a decision to incorporate the Institutional Strengthening project into the HPMP.

№ Activities                Implementing Agency
1 Improvement of legislation  UNIDO
2 Customs officers training  UNEP
3 Technical staff training  UNEP
4 R&R equipment, Identifiers  UNIDO
5 Laboratory assistance training  UNEP
6 Monitoring                         UNIDO
7 Institutional Strengthening 2012-2020   UNEP

Preparation for HCFC phase-out investment activities (stage II)
(refrigeration and air-conditioning manufacturing sector)
The objective of the HPMP - Stage II is to develop the second stage of a Compliance Strategy and corresponding Action Plan for the substances controlled under Annex C Group I (HCFCs) of the Montreal Protocol, for the period 2015 to 2020, such that the consumption of HCFCs is reduced by 35% from the baseline.

The Executive Committee reviewed the report presented with the request for renewal of the IS project for Turkmenistan (phase V) and noted with appreciation that the country continued the process to ratify the Kigali Amendment, amended the ODS law, maintains a robust licensing and quota system for HCFC, raised public awareness on ozone-layer protection, and reported 2018 and 2019 country programme implementation data and Article 7 data to the Fund and Ozone Secretariats, respectively, indicating that the
country is in compliance with Montreal Protocol. The Executive Committee also noted the submission of stage II of the HPMP accompanied by the request of the IS renewal, and the approval of the last tranche for stage I of the HPMP. The Executive Committee is, therefore, confident that the Government of Turkmenistan will continue implementing activities to enable the country to comply with the Montreal Protocol targets.

Migration plays a central role in the national development of Turkmenistan. However, due to the lack of capacities to collect, analyze and use statistical data, migration has not been factored in as a key variable within the national development plans and policies until today. The objective of the proposed project is to contribute to strengthened migration governance by the Government of Turkmenistan through evidence-based policy making. The project will aim to strengthen the capacity of the government in collecting and analyzing statistical data on migration, as well as their capacity to develop evidence-based policies. The first output will be delivered through a series of training sessions on gender-sensitive data collection and data analysis methodologies. The second output will be addressed through a series of workshops on evidence-based policy making for mid-level government professionals engaged in migration management and development of national sectoral policies.
Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility

Migration plays a central role in the national development of Turkmenistan. However, due to the lack of capacities to collect, analyze and use statistical data, migration has not been factored in as a key variable within the national development plans and policies until today. The objective of the proposed project is to contribute to strengthened migration governance by the Government of Turkmenistan through evidence-based policy making. The project will aim to strengthen the capacity of the government in collecting and analyzing statistical data on migration, as well as their capacity to develop evidence-based policies. The first output will be delivered through a series of training sessions on gender-sensitive data collection and data analysis methodologies. The second output will be addressed through a series of workshops on evidence-based policy making for mid-level government professionals engaged in migration management and development of national sectoral policies.
Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility

The project will (i) build about 1,100 kilometers (km) of new 110-kilovolt (kV), 220 kV, and 500 kV transmission lines; (ii) construct four new substations; and (iii) expand three existing substations. The project will cover four of the five regions of Turkmenistan, and will help establish an interconnected national transmission grid to improve reliability and energy efficiency of the network. Hydrocarbon-rich Turkmenistan has been an exporter of baseload power to its neighbors, notably Afghanistan. The reinforced transmission network is an essential prerequisite for improving power supply reliability for domestic consumers and current and expanded future electricity exports.
Electric power transmission and distribution (centralised grids)

To increase the productivity and competitiveness of the agro-food sector through activities aimed to improve the agro-food production, processing and marketing and to strengthen the capacity of Turkmen agriculture institutions.

The IFCA contribution will finance technical assistance in the form of a project identification study (the ''Study'') which will likely result in investments in the municipal infrastructure sector. The Study aims to identify ways in which the EBRD, alongside other IFCA eligible IFIs, can engage with the municipal infrastructure sector in Turkmenistan, including water, wastewater, solid waste management and district heating.

In the programming period 2014-17 EU's strategy and priorities are evolving as the country achieved Upper Middle Income status.This requires drafting of a phasing-out strategy from bilateral cooperation, a rationalization of resources and the concentration of funds on a single focal sector providing qualified expertise in order to achieve greater focus, sustainability and impact.The overall objective of the project is to ensure more effective and efficient implementation of EU funded programmes.
Public sector policy and administrative management
Support to the Education Sector in Turkmenistan  - Support to the Education Sector in Turkmenistan
Support for Public Administration Capacity Building in Turkmenistan - Support for Public Administration Capacity Building in Turkmenistan
Public sector policy and administrative management

Under the Advice for Small Businesses in Turkmenistan project, the EBRD will seek to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs in Turkmenistan by strengthening business management, encouraging innovation and addressing skills gaps through the delivery of business advice and training. With a clearly defined focus on the private sector, the EBRD will seek to link with and reinforce complementary EU-funded activities under the Vocational Education theme.

The education system further improves the quality of learning at the primary and secondary levels, based on an upgraded curriculum
and the introduction of more interactive and child-centred classroom practices that support the development of both functional and
transferable life skills and competencies, the inclusion of children with disabilities, the effective socialization of both girls
and boys and their future adaptation to socioeconomic and climate-change risks.

bites.bite: In Turkmenistan, there are 9 funder_ref(s) working in 23 sector_group(s).
The largest sector_group is Other social infrastructure and services with 41 reports followed by Basic health with 39 reports.

The largest activity_url is http://d-portal.org/q.html?aid=XM-DAC-928-TM-2020-21-01.001.EU01.TKM01 with 9 reports followed by http://d-portal.org/q.html?aid=XM-DAC-928-TM-2020-21-01.001.EU01.TKM02 with 8 reports.
The largest funder_ref is XM-DAC-928 with 112 reports followed by UNDP with 46 reports.
The largest reporting is World Health Organization with 112 reports followed by United Nations Development Programme with 46 reports.
